Directions: Use the information to answer each question that follows.
Content: A student boils water for pasta and notices that the water boils faster when there is a lid on the pot. The student wonders whether energy can be saved by boiling water with the lid on. The student conducts an experiment to investigate the energy used to boil water at sea level under several different conditions. The experiment uses a hot plate with settings given in watts (W). The student compares the time it takes for the water to boil, in seconds (s), to the amount of electrical energy used, in watt-hours (Wh), for these four trials:
• Trial 1: low power (950 W) with lid off
• Trial 2: low power (950 W) with lid on
• Trial 3: high power (1,500 W) with lid off
• Trial 4: high power (1,500 W) with lid on
1. Heat the water at the low power setting in the pot with the lid off until it boils.
2. Record the time it takes for the water temperature to reach the boiling point. Temperature is measured in degrees Celsius (°C).
